page.title: 14The Buslingthorpe Dragon
page.content: The church contains the tomb of{Sir {John de Buslingthorpe.}The stone effigy lies cross-legged in chain mail armour. It had been inverted and used as a paving stone on the floor of the pulpit. Fortunately this preserved it in good condition. The legend is that a terrible {dragon}lived in the{Buslingthorpe marshes frightening and killing the local people.{Sir John}went out and slaughtered the dragon then drained the marshes so no more terrible beasts could lurk there. On still Autumn days the fog usually forms first and is thickest around{Buslingthorpe}and it is easy to imagine that the{dragon}is still there. By the way, we believe that {Buslingthorpe}is the longest place name in England which contains no letter used more than once.
